item.title: The “Fifth Property” of Euclidean Distances: Beyond the Metric Axioms
item.description: This post is heavily adapted from Chapter 5 of the book Convex Optimization & Euclidean Distance Geometry by Jon Dattorro. Metrics If you work with distances, you probably already know the four classical axioms: Non-negativity: $d(x, y) \ge 0$ Identity of Indiscernibles: $d(x, y) = 0 \iff x = y$ Symmetry: $d(x, y) = d(y, x)$ Triangle Inequality: $d(x, z) \le d(x, y) + d(y, z)$ But here is the catch: being a metric is not enough to be an Euclidean distance.
